awd_titl_txt: Conference: Botany 2022, PUI Section: Careers and Mentorship at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Faculty mentors of undergraduate researchers at public and private liberal arts colleges, community colleges, and branch campuses (collectively, PUIs) train over half the undergraduate STEM majors in the United States. Broadening participation in plant sciences, biodiversity sciences, and related disciplines requires recruiting and retaining faculty mentors with mentoring strategies that are effective for students from diverse backgrounds. Multiple training experiences for current and prospective PUI faculty will be held in conjunction with the BOTANY 2022 meeting, with the aims of broadening participation in the discipline and supporting STEM education at the undergraduate level.

A program of three, varied events at BOTANY 2022 will be supported. First, a half-day workshop in which participants receive training in inclusive mentoring strategies that support successful undergraduate research experiences, will be offered. Workshop participants will explore how their social identities influence the mentor-mentee relationship and will learn how to help students become active contributors in the mentoring relationship and develop a mentoring mosaic to support their success. Second, a career panel on applying to and interviewing for positions at PUIs, intended for graduate students, postdocs, and their faculty mentors, will be convened. Finally, a networking event for all faculty and individuals interested in botany at PUIs will be held to aid in developing local and disciplinary networks for post-meeting collaborations in support of undergraduate research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Botany is the annual meeting of the Botanical Society of America (BSA), the American Society of Plant Taxonomy, The Society of Herbarium Curators, The American Bryological and Lichenological Society, The International Association for Plant Taxonomy, and the American Fern Society. This conference brings together academic and professional researchers as well as undergraduate and graduate students working on all aspects of botany and plant science. Botany2022 was held July 24–27 at the Dena’ina Center in Anchorage Alaska. The conference included plenary lectures, oral presentations, and poster sessions on botanical research. 

Approximately 50 faculty and students from at least 39 institutions participated in the Botany 2022, PUI Section Conference on Careers and Mentorship at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions. The grant supported a series of satellite events at the larger Botany 2022 conference so that faculty with limited travel opportunities from primarily undergraduate institutions could attend a research conference, but also participate in the professional development opportunities described below. It also supported an additional event at Botany 2023 which provided information to faculty and postdocs about seeking funding for undergraduate research at primarily undergraduate institutions for 12 faculty from as many institutions. In total, 17 persons were provided support to attend these events, and additional PUI faculty and postdocs attended the events. Funding decisions were based on competitive written applications in which participants described their need and the benefits conferred by financial support.

On Sunday morning July 24, 2022, A half-day workshop titled “You are welcome here: Cultivating inclusive research labs at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions” was hosted. The workshop was led by Dr. Kimberly Mulligan to support principal investigators (PIs) and future PIs at primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) as they strive to design and maintain an inclusive and equitable research lab group. Dr. Mulligan led the workshop focused on aligning expectations in mentoring. Summary slides and handouts were made available electronically to all participants and to members of the Botany PUI Section. A complete summary of the event was included in the PUI Section Report to the Botanical Society of America, available to all members of the society. On Monday, July 25, a networking event was hosted to introduce participants with similar research interests, locations, and courses so that they could exchange resources, content, and strategies for effective teaching and research with undergraduate students in the plant sciences. There were 21 participants. By the end of the event, there were many announcements about ongoing and future searchers for faculty positions at PUIs. On Tuesday, July 26, 2022, an informative panel discussion was held. The panel discussion and questions focused on applying for jobs at PUIs and what teaching and research at a PUI is like. Positions at PUIs involve a balance of teaching, research & undergraduate mentorship, and service that differs from expectations at R1 universities; job advertisements for PUI positions vary accordingly. There were at least 20 participants, but more arrived late or had to leave the discussion early and did not sign the attendance sheet. This career panel discussion led to a publication in the Plant Science Bulletin authored by the co-PIs and panel participants titled “Preparing for a Faculty Position at a Primarily Undergraduate Institution (PUI)” in the Plant Science Bulletin. Volume 69 issue 1, 2023 pages 13–22. To further broader participation and include participants who could not attend the Botany2022 Conference because of unexpected costs, family emergencies, or COVID-19, an additional event was organized as an informational lunch meeting at Botany 2023. The lunch focused on funding for research at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs), or in collaboration with faculty at PUIs. Representatives from NSF presented various opportunities and section members shared non-NSF opportunities. The event was open to all faculty, especially future PUI faculty and their mentors. There were 12 participants, and an extended, informative question-and-answer session with the NSF representatives about challenges and needs at PUIs. The slides from this presentation and a curated list of funding opportunities for plant researchers at PUIs are available to all Botany PUI section members.
